text:
It is hard to imagine anything more important than saving a child from dying a preventable death.
 
That’s why I’m grateful for the many global leaders who came together this week to pledge a combined $9 billion to Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance.
 
Gavi has helped vaccinate more than 1 billion children against some of the world’s deadliest diseases—saving millions of lives and making our whole world healthier and safer.
 
At a critical moment when some are turning their back on the world’s poorest children—including the U.S. government, which has threatened to withdraw funding that Gavi depends on—it is more important than ever that we stand behind Gavi and its lifesaving, essential work.
 
Thank you to President von der Leyen and the European Commission for leading this effort and making vaccine access the global priority it deserves to be.
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
As the @gatesfoundation marks its 25th anniversary, I am so proud of the impact the foundation and its partners have had around the world. I’ve seen so many powerful examples of what that impact looks like: A child receiving a lifesaving vaccine. A woman being able to decide if and when to become pregnant. Farmers breaking their families out of poverty thanks to more productive harvests. These stories behind the statistics will have effects that ripple across generations, and I know the next twenty years will unlock many more. 
https://t.co/dUy9UxAgXj
author: Melinda French Gates

text: When women can decide if and when to have children, they are healthier, their families are more prosperous, and their children get a better start in life. Everyone benefits, and the positive effects ripple for generations. The U.S. decision to end support for family planning programs around the world will cost lives and claim futures that should have been bright. https://t.co/Oh4iWSTYcV
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
For more than 50 years, leaders of both parties have championed Title X, a program that funds basic healthcare for women, especially low-income women. By removing access to essential services from family planning to cancer screenings, this funding freeze puts the lives and futures of the most vulnerable at risk.
https://t.co/PY1dFPvfnt
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
Thanks to Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, more than 1 billion children have been immunized against the world’s deadliest diseases, like tuberculosis and malaria. Now the U.S. government is reportedly planning to end its support for Gavi—support that’s been critical to this progress for nearly 25 years.

It breaks my heart to think that more than a million children in low-income countries could die over the next five years because of this decision.

It’s no exaggeration to say that the world’s success in immunizing children is one of the greatest achievements in history. It’s also one of the hardest-won. Mothers around the world line up for hours in the heat to get vaccines for their children, women travel through mountains on foot to administer them, and thousands of scientists dedicate their lives to developing them—all because there’s nothing more important than saving the life of a child.

Leaders must reconsider the plan to end support for Gavi. Unraveling one of the most effective systems in global health would be an absolutely devastating choice.
author: Melinda French Gates

text: Rosalynn Carter led heroic efforts to get caregivers more support and recognition, and her advocacy has long inspired my own work on this issue. I'm thankful for the ways @RCICaregiving continues to honor her legacy by championing caregivers across the country 💞 #NationalCaregiversDay
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
Today I am thinking of the people I’ve met around the world—children, parents, health workers, teachers—who will be harmed by the Trump administration’s decision to try to dismantle USAID and walk back U.S. leadership in global health and poverty reduction.

I’m thinking, too, about the dangerous ripple effects this will cause. In an increasingly interconnected world, we’re all better off when lifesaving medicines are developed and delivered, when disease outbreaks are halted, and when nations lift themselves out of poverty.

Strong leaders throughout history have understood that foreign aid builds a heathier, safer, more prosperous world—and that’s a goal everyone should be able to get behind.
author: Melinda French Gates

text: Contraceptives are a life-changing, life-saving tool that women around the world depend on to safeguard their health, their families, and their futures. But today the Trump Administration acted to reinstate dangerous global health funding restrictions that will limit access to contraceptives and other essential reproductive health services—which evidence shows will cost women and children their lives. I have heard from women firsthand about what happens when they lose the right to decide if and when to get pregnant, and it is why I am so steadfastly committed to putting more power in the hands of more women all over the world.
author: Melinda French Gates

text: It cannot be emphasized enough: Cutting global funding for reproductive care and other essential health services would be devastating—and even deadly—for women and children around the world. The stories of the women in this piece by @NickKristof show why. https://t.co/2DrreHdy6F
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
My hero Jimmy Carter was a peacemaker, a public servant,  a man of faith,  a devoted partner to Rosalynn—and a Guinea worm’s worst nightmare. I knew him best as a global health advocate and deeply admired his dedication to taking on diseases that impact the world’s poorest people, like Guinea worm disease. 

When President Carter left office, there were more than 3.5 million cases of this painful, debilitating disease around the world each year. This year, thanks in no small part to the work of the Carter Center, that number was down to single digits. He dreamed of outliving the last Guinea worm—and came incredibly close.

As he traveled around the world meeting with heads of state, monitoring elections, visiting clinics, and building homes, he took time to connect to the people he met. He believed in removing the barriers that separated a man like him—a former President and Nobel Prize winner—from people living with the realities of poverty and disease.

One of my favorite teachings says: “To know that even one life has breathed easier because you lived, this is to have succeeded.” We honor President Carter by remembering that because of him, life is healthier, better, and safer not just for one life, but for millions.
author: Melinda French Gates

text: Josseli Barnica’s story is heartbreaking and maddening—and it shows just how much is on the line this election. Make a plan to vote, make your voice heard, and make sure our government knows that protecting women’s health isn’t optional. https://t.co/4WE7gdTBqH
author: Melinda French Gates

text: As part of my $1 billion commitment I announced in May, I’m excited to launch #ActionforWomensHealth—a $250 million global open call that will fund grassroots organizations working to improve women’s mental and physical health. Learn more + apply here: https://t.co/Ii8kt1mTgz
author: Melinda French Gates

text: This new data sheds much-needed light on the heroic work of caregivers over 50—and it makes a strong case for giving them more support. https://t.co/OkZB1sFIZM
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
It’s no secret that women’s health has long been underfunded & overlooked, with complex & even fatal consequences for women & their families. This effort to drive more investment in women’s health research is incredibly necessary & important.
https://t.co/47KZAKcikO
author: Melinda French Gates

text: So proud of my youngest, Phoebe, for using her voice to advocate for reproductive freedom and ensure women get the care they deserve 👏🏼
author: Melinda French Gates

text: “As women in this society, I think we all struggle with not-enoughness.” I really appreciated what @MichelleObama shared about navigating perfectionism in a world that constantly asks you to prove yourself. Watch our full conversation: https://t.co/vZYVsVmY9Q https://t.co/zjphTiYvwJ
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
There is so much riding on the election in November. We need a leader who will stand up for reproductive freedom. A leader who understands that supporting caregivers leads to healthier families and a stronger economy. A leader who knows that when women have their full power in society, we all thrive.

I am supporting Vice President Kamala Harris because she is that leader. She has an inspiring vision for America—and she has the experience to make it a reality. The issues she prioritizes are the ones that matter to voters. She has been crisscrossing the country to make the case for reproductive rights while courts and state legislatures are trying to take them away. She spearheaded legislation to eliminate racial disparities in maternal health care. She is leading on policies to make paid leave, child care, and elder care more affordable for families.

I am proud to support Vice President Harris. During her years in the White House, she has proven that she knows how to lead through crises while pushing for the change we need. I want her fighting for our country for the next four years.
author: Melinda French Gates

text: Twelve years ago, I spoke out publicly for the first time about contraceptive access. Here’s a look at the women who inspired me to speak on this issue—and why I remain committed to protecting reproductive freedom. Women know what’s right for themselves and their families. https://t.co/FNsauTmZQa
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
Sociologist @JessicaCalarco hit the nail on the head when she said: “Other countries have social safety nets. The U.S. has women.”

That, she argues, is a policy choice—and it's "leaving our whole society sicker, sadder, and more stressed." https://t.co/XswYC6spEc
author: Melinda French Gates

text: Never did I think I'd see the day when women were one court ruling away from being able to receive emergency care. Women’s rights, women’s health, and even women’s lives are under attack. Today, it was access to emergency care. Tomorrow, it could be access to birth control or fertility treatments. The best way to channel our anger and fight back is to join together, raise our voices, and exercise our political power by voting this November.
author: Melinda French Gates

text: Even though every single one of us will either be a caregiver or need one at some point in our lives, our country still hasn’t prioritized investing in care. These results make a strong case for change.
author: Melinda French Gates

text: Not all caregivers are adults. The lack of accessible and affordable caregiving options in the U.S. forces many children—upwards of 5.4 million—to care for family members while going to school and juggling other responsibilities. https://t.co/pkySN6fWmO
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
I’ve never endorsed a presidential candidate before. But this year’s election stands to be so enormously consequential for women and families that, this time, I can’t stay quiet.

Women deserve a leader who cares about the issues they face and is committed to protecting their safety, their health, their economic power, their reproductive rights, and their ability to freely and fully participate in a functioning democracy. In this election, the contrast couldn’t be greater, and the stakes couldn’t be higher.

I will be voting for President Biden.

https://t.co/Lmn7qJzADI
author: Melinda French Gates

text: Today’s Supreme Court decision is welcome news, but the fight for reproductive rights is far from over. Someone else will file a lawsuit. Another state will pass legislation restricting women’s options. The only way to stop these attacks on women’s autonomy is to make sure that women have the political power to set their own agenda, instead of having their fundamental rights depend on someone else’s. We all have a role to play in this fight. Raise your voice. And vote in November. Your health and your future should be in your hands.
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
Each one of these leaders has an important perspective on what needs to be done to improve women’s health and wellbeing.

As part of my new $1 billion commitment to advance women’s power globally, these leaders will each receive a $20 million fund to distribute to charitable organizations of their choice. I can’t wait to see the landscape of opportunities to support women and girls through their eyes.
author: Melinda French Gates

text: Such great insights from Pivotal’s partners on how to support young people’s mental health and wellbeing in a tech-filled world. I especially loved the advice on how adults can be better allies to young people 💞 #MentalHealthAwarenessMonth
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
Vaccines are one of the best tools we have to keep our loved ones healthy, prevent outbreaks from spreading, and help our communities flourish.

By working together to improve access to vaccines, we can get closer to a future where no one dies from a preventable death.
author: Melinda French Gates

text: If we can fix this country’s broken caregiving system, then we can enable women to more fully step in to their power, and as a result, improve society as a whole. #CareCantWait https://t.co/3SMMos1fYE
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
Anyone who’s cared for a sick or aging loved one knows that it can be a deeply meaningful experience—and also a daunting one.

Our country must do more to get caregivers like Ruth the support they need so they can be there for the people they love. https://t.co/5bqikZK0If
author: Melinda French Gates

text: For #IWD2024, I joined @ABC @GMA to talk about a few promising tools to support women’s health and empower them to plan their futures. Everyone benefits when women are healthy—which is why we need more investments in innovations that meet their needs. https://t.co/bkkOZU5F06
author: Melinda French Gates

text: The @WTA was founded on the idea of equal opportunity, and that’s what our campaign #WomenChangeTheGame is about. Together, we’re working to level the playing field in women’s health.
author: Melinda French Gates

text: I’m deeply concerned about the Alabama Supreme Court’s ruling and its potential impact on people’s access to reproductive health care in Alabama and across the country. Decisions about whether, when, and how to have children should belong to families—not judges and lawmakers.
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
On #NationalCaregiversDay, I’m thinking about the need for a caregiving system that enables everyone to care for themselves and their loved ones on their own terms.

@pivotalventures' partner @CaringAcrossGen is building a nationwide movement to transform the way we care. https://t.co/Jrppl89Dj1
author: Melinda French Gates

text: In her new book, Dear Black Girls, @_ajawilson22 writes openly about her experiences with grief and anxiety—topics she wishes people talked about more, especially in the Black community. Hear what she has to say about these hard and important subjects 💞 https://t.co/CsOG1r5BRr
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
I loved talking with economist @ProfEmilyOster
about our many shared interests—including maternal health, women’s contributions to medicine and economics, and using data to improve women’s lives. Check out our full conversation 👇🏼 
https://t.co/jUXyFaJmJB https://t.co/iv4izuX14G
author: Melinda French Gates

text: Congratulations @smritiirani on the launch of the Alliance for Global Good – Gender Equity and Equality at #WEF24. Proud to partner in this important mission to narrow the gender gap in health, digital education, and enterprise through collective action. https://t.co/1lUj4OuGDC
author: Melinda French Gates

text: It is so important for kids to feel safe, loved, and supported. That's why efforts to help young people access mental health care are essential. I love the powerful ways these organizations are showing up for students ⬇️
author: Melinda French Gates

text:
When women’s health improves, it unlocks better outcomes for everyone.

@WEF's new Global Alliance for Women’s Health, chaired by @AnitaZaidi & @nisia_trindade, will do important work to get women’s health the attention and resources it deserves. https://t.co/nafDqWqfur
author: Melinda French Gates
